column4: does anyone here know how to downgrade a package or reverse a distupdate?
if that's the right word
hmm, that's unpleasant
you can *try* downgrading single packages using « sudo apt-get install packagename=version », but it's not guaranteed to succeed

hmm.  The real issue is that the current kernel version (2.6.22) seems to have broken my sister's laptop's suspend/hibernate function, which is pretty important for a student laptop.  Upgrading to a less stable 2.6.23 would also be conceivable, how workable is that (including a working ndiswrapper + fglrx with it)?

if it's just the kernel, you don't need to downgrade at all. the old kernel should have remained installed. just go to the GRUB menu and select it, instead of selecting the latest kernel. to make the change persistent, edit the "default" line in /boot/grub/menu.lst
I'll test that again, but the last time I tried the older kernel it simply didn't work.  Perhaps I should attempt a reinstallation of it?
however, Gutsy *always* had 2.6.22 as far as i'm aware
I upgraded her computer to Gutsy from Feisty to show her how cool linux + free updates are.  Bad idea ;)
so 2.6.20-16 is still there
uhm, isn't that the Feisty kernel though? did you upgrade from Feisty?
but Gutsy (not Feisty) worked *before* the very latest upgrade?

no... 2.6.22 was the current kernel version present when I updated her computer, so she has 2.6.20-16 from when she had Feisty and 2.6.22-14, the current Gutsy kernel.  Her computer worked fine when I was able to select the older kernel, but for some reason it won't boot off of it now.

you could try reinstalling version 2.6.22-14.46, which should be the original Gutsy version i think (now it's .47, updated a couple of days ago). i really don't guarantee anything though - and if it then doesn't boot, you *may* be left with no booting kernel.
no worries, I have a liveCD and am quite used to chrooting ;)

sudo apt-get install linux-generic=2.6.22-16 didn't work, and I'm guessing it's because there's another level of versioning.  Where do I check for the packages in a repo to get the exact versions available?
sorry for the newb questions, I guarantee I do google searches before them
sudo apt-get install linux-image-2.6.22-14-generic=2.6.22-14.46 (and same with modules etc, do "dpkg -l | grep linux")
ok, so dpkg -l will list all available versions of packages?
so that in the future I'll know that 2.6.22-16.46 is the right one, I mean

no, it will list what you have installed. but note that in linux-image-2.6.22-14-generic, the "2.6.22-14" is NOT a version (well it is, but technically it's just part of the package name), the version is 2.6.22-14.47, and before that it was 2.6.22-14.46, and this latter version should still be installable
ok, thanks.  All of the 2.6.22 versions have this problem, though, it's an upstream bug.  I've tried to reinstall 2.6.20-16.32 but it's not available :(
